cohort.reelThemIn: The floor is not my son, but I will raise it
cohort.bio: NSS is amazing , btw my bio isnt finished

cohort.reelThemIn: Life is full of "Ah-Ha!" moments, 80% of those moments have come from my time at NSS.
cohort.bio: Growing up I spent my days hiking trails and exploring parks. Biology always came naturally for me and my love for learning about nature never ended. After college I worked as both a Park Ranger and as a Zookeeper. In both positions I often found myself being more technologically interested than my colleagues and was usually the one to fix old electronics and troubleshoot new equipment. I welcomed the idea of sensors and programs that could automate the work for us and we could monitor those systems adjusting parameters to make them work as efficiently as possible. This interest followed me everywhere, I taught myself about most of what I know about computers in my free time and love making tech projects at home too. When I started grabbing code from Github and learning that I could write code too, I knew then that I wanted to make a career switch. My goal as a Software Developer is to design applications for the future and to increase the efficiency in our lives both time and energy, while mitigating the loss of our natural resources.

cohort.reelThemIn: “Engineers believe that if it ain’t broke, it doesn’t have enough features yet.” – Scott Adams
cohort.bio: Computers have been a part of my life since I was around 10 years old. Tinkering with computers inspired my career in technology when I started using that knowledge to fix other family member's computers to make spending money in middle school. I became certified at John A Logan College and my entry point into the tech world was repairing and troubleshooting the computers for local small businesses. I’ve been in the space for 6+ years, worked at Hype Media for 3 of them later as a DevOps Engineer for a non-profit. Finally, I have a love for helping companies and enjoy doing so by helping build scalable applications on a team utilizing modern technologies and solutions.

cohort.reelThemIn: When she asks, "What is your idea of the perfect date?", don't say "YYYY-MM-DD".
cohort.bio: Lifelong piano player turns software developer. I have a passion for creative thinking, working in teams, and keeping things efficient! I quickly discovered a love for software development as I noticed its unique combination of mathematics and art. I am excited to see where my career in software development takes me!

cohort.reelThemIn: It's creepy when your code works flawlessly the first time
cohort.bio: Hi My name is Cheo. I'm a Nashville-based developer. I have been programming as a hobby on/off for years. I started with C++ in highschool and dabbled with a bit of other languages since then. In colelge, I used Prolog for a computational linguistics course where we drove robotic cars using our voice. Due to health reasons after graduating, I could no longer do Peace Corp on medical grounds, so I continued learning at a local community college and state school. Doing so taught me to plan, build, and automate tools which eased my workload in the transportation/logistics/freight shipping industries. It was not until I was laid off in December of 20200, that I decided to return from my hobby hiatus and enrolled at the Nashville Software School. NSS reinforced my skillset and taught me to use the latest technologies. In my free time I like to catch up on (computational) linguistics, explore, and volunteer, particularly with the homeless. I look forward to collaborating with you on future endeavors.

cohort.reelThemIn: Deleted code is debugged code. - Jeff Sickel
cohort.bio: Throughout my life I've found that I am happiest when I am troubleshooting issues whether it be repairing faulty light fixtures, diagnosing and repairing a spotty RF connection, or restoring internet to a local business. This love for problem solving is what led me to pursue a career as a software developer.

cohort.reelThemIn: "If you're not moving, you're not going anywhere."
cohort.bio: Before venturing into the tech world, it was a love for music that drove me to pursue a career in the industry. The physicality of an instrument like the drum set combined with a deep desire to collaborate with others creatively is what drove me to set my life on that course. The evolution of the music industry and music technology brought me more and more in touch with technology as the years went on. The collaborative nature of software development paired with the creative and problem solving elements seemed very enticing to me, which ultimately led me to NSS. The learning process has been challenging, but also equally as satisfying.

cohort.reelThemIn: "There is no innovation and creativity without failure. Period." - Brene Brown
cohort.bio: As a gardener who is passionate about climate justice, for years I thought the best way to help others was to teach them skills in self-sustainability. It wasn't until January of 2020 that I discovered the link between technology and sustainability. I've always been an organized and detailed person, so software development felt like a good fit for me. After many conversations and recommendations, I ended up at Nashville Software School and have been loving every minute. Now, I am excited to develop creative solutions for the future!

cohort.reelThemIn: "If you are feeling froggy then leap"
cohort.bio: After working almost every job in the restaurant I decided to pursue a career in software development. My skills problem solving, and adapting on the fly in a high paced team environment have helped guide my decision to enter the programming world.

cohort.reelThemIn: ["hip", "hip"]
cohort.bio: My passion lies in creating solutions based on personal and business needs through data analysis, developmental research, and a constant strive to learn more. I enjoy the challenges of developing novel ideas into real-world applications. My colleagues would describe me as a driven, resourceful individual with a positive, proactive attitude when faced with adversity. I have strong technical skills and an academic background in software development as well as in Biochemistry and Cellular and Molecular Biology.

cohort.reelThemIn: 4 hours of debugging can save you 15 minutes of reading documentation.
cohort.bio: I began my career in software development while working in social work. My passion for helping others and solving problems made me great at my job, but the emotionally taxing environment pushed me to pursue new opportunities. In my search I discovered a passion for coding and started a new journey. Learning and working as a developer is a refreshing challenge. I love using my skills to find creative solutions to problems, and I am excited to pursue new opportunities to further my career.

cohort.reelThemIn: "Do you ever find python constricting?"
cohort.bio: Starting my career in education has inspired a lifelong love for learning. The urge to challenge myself and explore new ideas led me to an exciting learning opportunity at Nashville Software School, and soon into my first junior development role . I am looking for an exciting opportunity to feed my curiosity and expand my coding knowledge. My natural creativity and ability to solve complex problems has allowed for a smooth transition from teaching to technology.

cohort.reelThemIn: Deleted code is debugged code
cohort.bio: Working at a startup the last few years taught me how to wear many hats, learn new skills quickly, and juggle an always changing list of projects and goals. My favorite projects were always those that challenged me or required digging into data to solve a problem. I started looking for an opportunity where I could work on those types of projects every day and found that Software Development rewards all of those capabilities and also provides tremendous opportunities for growth and a culture of continuous learning and improvement.

cohort.reelThemIn: I wrote a script to automate coming up with this original and unique sentence.
cohort.bio: I'm a full stack software developer in Nashville, TN. Born and raised in the same city, I studied music theory and composition in college. I worked my way through the music industry in Nashville, slowly finding myself in more and more technical roles - editing, producing, recording - until I found a special niche that serves both my fascination and the musician community, building and repairing guitar amplifiers while studying electronic engineering. I began studying what I consider the digital counterpart of circuit building with Python and JavaScript, ultimately enrolling in a 6 month bootcamp at Nashville Software School.

cohort.reelThemIn: Do not underestimate the aggregation of marginal gains!
cohort.bio: A world traveler, business manager, and software developer with an insatiable intellectual curiosity, passion for problem solving, as well as highly detail oriented. My goal is to utilize my diverse experiences in business as a software developer and continue to learn new ways in which software development can solve real world problems.

cohort.reelThemIn: A person needs the humility to know that preparation is necessary & the confidence to know success is possible.
cohort.bio: The first code I wrote was a number guessing game for a TI-83 calculator in 9th grade. The manual showed me how to access a random number generator and the rest was very basic commands I learned by reading through the code of other calculator applications I had. Since then I have incorporated coding into my work and life every chance I get to boost my productivity and reduce redundant activity. I have always enjoyed and had an interest in coding but it wasn’t until I was in an accident and in bed for 8 weeks that I learned I really loved building things with code and wanted to take my abilities to the next level. Nashville Software School has provided me with that opportunity in an incredible way. I have learned more in the few months I have attended that I ever thought I would and it has sparked a deep love for the challenge of learning to code.

cohort.reelThemIn: Passionately tweeting customer service complaints since 2008
cohort.bio: After a year of change, I find myself with a diverse group of friends, diving into a big new world, and yet in some ways for me, back into an old one. I began my tech journey out of college, survived the 2001 bubble, lived a world of music for twenty years, and am now building on that original foundation with new skills and fresh eyes.

cohort.reelThemIn: "Machines need love too" - The Terminator
cohort.bio: With an educational background in English, language, and writing, upon moving to Nashville, I began working in customer experience for e-commerce and tech companies. I developed an interest in the user experience surrounding technology—it allowed me to bolster my problem-solving and communication skills, and eventually, led me to coding. I took part in a 3-week jumpstart course at Nashville Software School to test the waters, and I immediately dove into the opportunity to enroll in their 6-month full-stack bootcamp. My career goal is to help build a product that makes a positive impact. I’m eager to learn, not afraid to ask questions, and I'm excited to find a role that enables me to constantly learn, grow, and creatively tackle problems. I've been on the search for a career I love, and I felt right at home in the world of software development.

cohort.reelThemIn: "You can't steal second base and keep your foot on first"
cohort.bio: Not What I Planned…Prior to beginning my journey in software development, I worked as a freelance creative and professional services consultant. During this time, I developed a love for web content and managing websites using content management systems. Oftentimes, I came into positions and the websites were old and outdated, so I was tasked with learning basic HTML and CSS skills as well as eventually moving websites to a newer platform. After 10 years of developing and maintaining websites using content management systems, I decided I wanted to know the ""how and why"" behind websites and applications. Software development will allow me to grow my knowledge as I continue to do something I have grown to love. Sidenote: My personal and professional mission has always been to help revitalize small businesses, non-profits, and associations by telling their stories to increase impact and finding ways to provide extraordinary services and solutions with limited resources, I hope to continue my mission in some way on my new journey!

cohort.reelThemIn: "Tell me and I forget. Teach me and I remember. Involve me and I learn." -Benjamin Franklin
cohort.bio: I ventured into this field of web development, with a background in jazz vocal performance, classical piano performance, and as music teacher of many years. My interest in web development stemmed greatly from the need of building my own website for my music career (and never being satisfied with the “status quo” website templates); also, I saw a glaring gap in private music teachers and music organizations having a functional up to date website. Often times I would tell myself, “You should figure out how to do this…” but then scoff at the idea. When I finally succumbed to my intuition pulling me to this path, I started to dabble on my own with coding classes online and found myself very intrigued. From that moment, I decided to give coding my best effort by attending a coding bootcamp. That decision led me to NSS. Several friends and former colleagues of mine attended NSS and spoke highly of the program. I have gathered hands on knowledge and training in many different coding languages at NSS, such as: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React, Python, SQL, and Django. I am excited to begin my career as a professional junior web developer and will be graduating from NSS on June 25th, 2021. I love to learn and am excited to continue this journey as a professional web developer.
